noun.description: A device or enclosure designed to catch and retain animals, typically by allowing entry but not exit or by catching hold of a part of the body.
A situation in which people lie in wait to make a surprise attack.
examples: we were fed false information by a double agent and walked straight into a trap

noun.description: A container or device used to collect a specified thing.
examples: one fuel filter and water trap are sufficient on the fuel system

noun.description: A light, two-wheeled carriage pulled by a horse or pony.
A device for hurling an object such as a clay pigeon into the air to be shot at.
A person's mouth (used in expressions to do with speaking)
Percussion instruments, typically in a jazz band.
A place where drugs are sold.
An act of trapping the ball.

origin: Late 18th century: from Swedish trapp, from trappa stair (because of the often stair-like appearance of its outcroppings).
